content: Honestly? I'm exhausted. [Several nods around the room] Everything is so divisive. I own a small business and I just want someone who's going to focus on the basics - keep the roads fixed, keep the schools decent, and maybe not make everything into a fight.
participant_profile: F, 52, Small business owner (gift shop), Troy, independent, divorced, two adult children, voted split ticket 2020
preceding_moderator_q: Good evening everyone, and thank you for being here. I want to start by just getting a sense of how you're all feeling about things in Michigan right now. What's on your mind when you think about the direction of the state? Anyone can jump in.

content: That's exactly it. The exhaustion is real. I feel like we've been in crisis mode for... what, six years now? Seven? I just want things to feel normal again.
participant_profile: F, 49, HR director at mid-size company, Birmingham, married, one teenager, concerned about "where the country is headed"
preceding_moderator_q: Good evening everyone, and thank you for being here. I want to start by just getting a sense of how you're all feeling about things in Michigan right now. What's on your mind when you think about the direction of the state? Anyone can jump in.

content: For me it's the economy that keeps me up at night. I'm doing okay at the plant - we're actually hiring right now, which is good - but I see prices going up everywhere. Gas was killing me this summer. Groceries are through the roof. My wife does the shopping and she comes home stressed every time.
participant_profile: M, 38, Manufacturing supervisor at auto parts supplier, Pontiac, union member (UAW), registered Dem but describes self as "not loyal to any party"
preceding_moderator_q: Good evening everyone, and thank you for being here. I want to start by just getting a sense of how you're all feeling about things in Michigan right now. What's on your mind when you think about the direction of the state? Anyone can jump in.

content: The inflation is real. I'm retired, fixed income, and I've had to adjust our budget significantly. We're not hurting, but I know people who are.
participant_profile: M, 61, Retired GM engineer, Bloomfield Hills, registered Republican who "couldn't vote for Trump twice," fiscal conservative
preceding_moderator_q: Good evening everyone, and thank you for being here. I want to start by just getting a sense of how you're all feeling about things in Michigan right now. What's on your mind when you think about the direction of the state? Anyone can jump in.

content: Gas, obviously. It was over five dollars a gallon in June. That's insane. And groceries - a box of cereal is like six bucks now. Milk. Eggs went crazy for a while.
participant_profile: M, 38, Manufacturing supervisor at auto parts supplier, Pontiac, union member (UAW), registered Dem but describes self as "not loyal to any party"
preceding_moderator_q: When you say prices are going up, what specifically are you noticing?

content: I run my own business, electrical work, and my material costs are up probably 30 percent from two years ago. Wire, panels, everything. I have to pass that on to customers and I hate it. Some people look at me like I'm trying to rip them off.
participant_profile: M, 42, Electrician, own business, Waterford, Catholic, Trump 2016/Biden 2020, wife is more liberal
preceding_moderator_q: When you say prices are going up, what specifically are you noticing?

content: For me it's rent. I'm a nurse, I make decent money, but trying to find an apartment in Royal Oak that doesn't cost half my paycheck is impossible. I have student loans on top of that. I'm 34 and I feel like I'm never going to be able to buy a house.
participant_profile: F, 34, Nurse at Beaumont Hospital, Royal Oak, single, student loan debt, first-time swing voter
preceding_moderator_q: When you say prices are going up, what specifically are you noticing?

content: The housing market here is crazy. I'm in real estate and I've never seen anything like it. Houses going 50, 60 thousand over asking. Cash offers. Regular families can't compete.
participant_profile: F, 56, Real estate agent, West Bloomfield, empty nester, very engaged on local issues, Jewish community active
preceding_moderator_q: When you say prices are going up, what specifically are you noticing?

content: And then you add what's happening in the schools... [sighs] I'm a teacher and we're dealing with so much right now. Kids are struggling after COVID - the learning loss is real, the behavior issues, the mental health stuff. We don't have enough staff. And then on top of that there's all this political fighting about what we can teach, what books can be in the library. It's demoralizing.
participant_profile: F, 45, Elementary school teacher, Rochester Hills, married, three kids, concerns about school safety and curriculum battles
preceding_moderator_q: When you say prices are going up, what specifically are you noticing?

content: It's like... parents are showing up to school board meetings screaming about critical race theory, which we don't even teach. We're just trying to help kids learn to read. There's this whole movement that seems to think teachers are the enemy. I've been teaching for twenty years and I've never felt less respected.
participant_profile: F, 45, Elementary school teacher, Rochester Hills, married, three kids, concerns about school safety and curriculum battles
preceding_moderator_q: Tell me more about that, P3. The political fighting around schools.

content: I have kids in the schools and I feel caught in the middle on this stuff. I don't think teachers are the enemy - my kids have had great teachers.
